title: Lab to find g with a spring loaded toy

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above. The setup includes a slightly modified spring pop-up toy with mass <math alttext="m sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which consists of a head and base attached by a spring with known spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and equilibrium length <math alttext="L sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the head of the toy is pressed down to the base and then released, the entire toy launches vertically from the table. The toy has been modified, as shown, to add a peg to hold additional masses. The students assume the added masses stay in contact with the toy throughout its motion. (a) Identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

Students are going to perform an experiment to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the lab using the setup shown. They are expected to find <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above. The setup includes a slightly modified spring pop-up toy with mass <math alttext="m sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which consists of a head and base attached by a spring with known spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and equilibrium length <math alttext="L sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the head of the toy is pressed down to the base and then released, the entire toy launches vertically from the table. The toy has been modified, as shown, to add a peg to hold additional masses. The students assume the added masses stay in contact with the toy throughout its motion. (a) Identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the acceleration due to gravity, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students performs the same experiment, but while watching a slow-motion recording of the experiment, they observe that during a couple of the trials, the masses lose contact with the toy at the maximum height and do not regain contact with the toy on the way down. If students follow the same procedure and analysis as described in part (b) through part (d), will the calculated magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> during the trials with masses losing contact be greater than, less than, or equal to the magnitude of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> obtained when the masses always stay in contact with the toy?

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
